title: gp surgery worker mum hangs herself after losing job
story: Victoria Pocock, , killed herself while her partner and their infant son were asleep upstairs.The -year-old was found hanging at the bottom of the stairs by her partner, who quickly put their -month-old son back to bed before dialling .The coroner heard that the operator told James Smith to cut his partner down and to start CPR but despite his best efforts and those of paramedics who later arrived, she was declared dead at the scene in Lambourn, near Hungerford, Berkshire.The inquest heard how Miss Pocock had battled depression for a number of years and had recently lost her job at a GP surgery.A statement from Dr Christa Teplickywas read out by Senior Berkshire Coroner Heidi Connor.Dr Teplicky said: Miss Pocock had been employed by a cleaning company that worked at the GP surgery.“The last time she was seen as a patient at the clinic was on March , but she was seen afterwards in the evenings when she was cleaning.Her main complaint was that she struggled to sleep. She was prescribed the anti-depressant Citalopram, as well as Zopiclone, a sleeping medication.When I saw her in December  she reported she was feeling much better and said she was looking forward to Christmas.Miss Pococks partner, Mr Smith, awoke at .am to hear their young son crying from his bedroom.When he had picked up the tot he looked down the stairs to see the boys mother hanging at the bottom of the stairs.The coroner, sitting in Reading, Berkshire, heard that Mr Smith put his son back to bed and called .Detective Constable Stephens went to the scene and also provided a report for Mrs Connor.He said: Mr Smith arrived back home on April  at about : pm and he found Miss Pocock drinking Corona beer.They went to bed and, at approximately :am, Mr Smith woke up and his partner was still asleep next to him.At .am he awoke to his son crying and went to get him up. He then noticed Miss Pococks body at the bottom of the stairs.He put his son back in his room and called . The operator instructed him to cut the cord around Miss Pococks neck and to start CPR.Paramedics attended the scene but she was declared le extinct at :am on April . When I arrived at the scene the deceased was lying on the floor. There were no apparent self-defence marks.Two red-inked letters were found, which were suicide notes. There was sad music playing from the television. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit second referendum
story: The PM ruled out holding a new vote on the EU or a General Election as she vowed to “deliver on Brexit”.She told BBC Breakfast: “People have had a vote, we voted in . The British people voted to leave the EU.I think its important for trust in politics and politicians that people can now feel that we as a Government are delivering on that vote.We gave people a choice, they chose. We should be delivering on that choice.Speaking at the Tory conference in Birmingham, Mrs May also insisted she won’t give in to Labour demands that she calls a General Election which could see her thrown out of power.The PM said: “We’re acting in the national interest - it is not in the national interest to have a General Election.”Asked how long she will last at No , Mrs May told the BBCs Today programme: I am in this for the long term - not just for the Brexit deal but also for the domestic agenda that we’re setting out at this conference.Mrs May admitted she was bruised by her clash with EU leaders at Salzburg last month - saying she needed a stf drink when she got home to husband Philip.She told LBC: I don’t remember what Philip said about it - I think when I got home he probably poured me a stf drink.Hitting out at bullying Eurocrats who wont be straight with the UK, the PM added: I’ve shown nothing but respect to the European Union and the UK deserves the same.But she also slapped down Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt for comparing Brussels bosses to the Soviet Union.The Prime Minister said: “As I sit around that table in the European Union, there are countries there who used to be part of the Soviet Union. They are now democratic countries.“I can tell you that the two organisations are not the same.”Mrs May will make her big conference speech tomorrow - although first she must see off a challenge from Boris Johnson who will address activists at a fringe event this afternoon.She insisted there wont be a repeat of last years meltdown where a bad cough meant she could barely finish her speech - telling LBC: I assume youve been able to hear everything Ive been saying.I will be ensuring that I will be standing up there and speaking strongly, and speaking strongly not just about getting the best Brexit deal for the UK but about the real opportunities there are for people here in the UK for the future.

title: passenger removed southwest airlines flight attendant n word
story: Witnesses said the vile passenger became infuriated after the flight attendant told her to put her table away for take-off on the flight from Chicago to Houston.Appalling footage shot on Sunday morning by another traveller showed the woman unleashing a tirade of abuse at staff.As she is being led off the plane she can be seen using the racial slur, labelling a member of staff a “stupid n*****” as she walks down the aisle.Her vile behaviour delayed the plane leaving by an hour but fellow passengers cheered as she was forced to deplane.She was met by local cops when she left the aircraft with the footage later being shared on social media.In other footage she was shown repeating the racial slur as she was removed from the aircraft.The passenger is as yet to be identied and has so far not been formally charged by police.Southwest Airlines told Fox News in a statement: “On Flight # with scheduled service from Chicago Midway to Houston Hobby on Saturday morning, our reports indicate that a Customer refused to comply with our Flight Crews instructions after boarding and before the flight departed Chicago.“The customer became unruly and verbally abusive toward our flight attendants, and the decision was made toto the gate to deplane the Customer, where she was met by local law enforcement officers.“Our employees handled the situation professionally with grace and class, and we do not condone or tolerate such profane and unruly behaviour on board our aircraft.“Once the customer deplaned the aircraft, the flight resumed to Houston Hobby, arriving about an hour later than originally scheduled.”Southwest Airlines made international headlines in April this year when a passenger was killed after being sucked out of a plane when shrapnel smashed through a window.Albuquerque banker and mother of two Jenner Riordan died after being partially sucked out of a Southwest plane window on April , .

title: mystery ancient rock carvings indian hunter gatherer civilisation ancient
story: The incredible images were found hidden beneath the soil atop hillocks in the Konkan region of Maharashtra.Experts believe the carvings, known as petroglyohs, were created by a hunter-gatherer community - because many of the images are drawings of animals, reports the BBC.The discovery suggests the civilisation could have migrated to India from Africa, where many of the animals depicted are found.And the archaeologists believe the drawings may be the oldest petroglyphs ever found, possibly dating back to the year , BC.The etchings were found by a group of explorers led by Sudhir Risbood and Manoj Marathe, who began searching for the images in earnest after observing a few in the area. Many were found in village temples and played a part in local folklore.Mr Risbood told the BBC: We walked thousands of kilometres. People started sending photographs to us and we even enlisted schools in our efforts to find them. We made students ask their grandparents and other village eldersthey knew about any other engravings. This provided us with a lot of valuable information.The pair found petroglphs in and around  villages, but only about five of the communities were aware that the images existed.Tejas Garge, director of the Maharashtra state archaeology department, also told the BBC: We have not found any pictures of farming activities. But the images depict hunted animals and theres detailing of animal forms. So this man knew about animals and sea creatures. That indicates he was dependent on hunting for food.All kinds of animals, including sharks, whales and turtles feature in the carvings, while human figures and geometrical designs also appear.Since the remarkable discovery, the researchers have been working to document the thousands of ancient carvings and spur efforts to preserve them.The state government has designated  million rupees to study  of the petroglyphs in greater detail, according to the BBC.

title: voodoo dolls russian city krasnodar mystery
story: Pensioners complained of blood pressure problems after seeing the spooky mannequins nailed to fences or propped up at bus stops.Residents called for an explanation of the dozens of weird dolls which reportedly appeared overnight in Zavetny in the Krasnodar region.There were also complaints to police.One resident told local media: “Creepy dolls are nailed to the pillars, fences and bus stops.“The little girl mannequins are pierced with needles and tied with black threads.”Another householder said: “Two were sitting at a bus stop.“A doll in a in a pink ball gown was found in the park.”A local warned: “A curse has been put on our village.”Several were eyeless or one-armed and were all dressed in girls clothes or school unorms.Head of the local council Dmitry Barkov said: “We have urgently brought together police officers to instruct them to calm people.”Police are studying CCTV cameras to identy those who distributed the dolls around the area even though planting voodoo dolls is not a crime, say reports.Meanwhile a local security officer has admitted dumping the mannequins - “the same size as a child” - at a local tip.Tatiana Kokoreva claimed they belonged to a local culture museum and were previously used in a puppet theatre which closed long ago.They were no longer needed and the security officer thought her daughter, a teacher, could use them.But the school rejected them as unsafe and too scary, so she dumped them.She insisted she was not responsible for dressing them up as voodoo dolls.

title: girl found walking streets pyjamas woodley berkshire
story: Thames Valley Police searched for the unattended girl, spotted wearing pink pyjamas, in two separate incidents in Woodley, Berkshire.She was first sighted at am on Saturday morning by a worried woman who called the police, triggering a frantic -hour manhunt.But the search was eventually called off because no one matching the little girls description was reported missing.Then cops got another call late on Monday night saying that a child in her pyjamas was completely alone near a parade of shops.Officers scrambled to a local Lidl where they found the seven-year-old by herself.They quickly established that it was the same girl who was spotted early on Saturday morning.After finding her, police reported the incidents to Social Services.It is understood that cops have interviewed her family.The girl, who has not been named, is believed to have let herself out of her home in darkness and then later ed home to her house in Woodley.Police said that as a result of both incidents, safeguarding measures were being enacted to protect the child.A spokesman for Thames Valley Police said: Officers attended the Lidl store in Headley Road, Woodley, at around pm following reports of a young girl walking alone in the precinct.On arrival, officers located a seven-year-old girl. The girl was ed home to her parents and is safe and well.From conversations with the girl, it is now known this girl is the same person that was reported being alone in the Woodley area on Saturday morning, and she is from the local area.We received reports that a young girl had been seen alone in Woodlands Avenue at around am on Saturday.Officers carried out signicant search activity in the area and spoke to members of the community, including local children and their families, however no children with welfare concerns were identied.

title: kate middleton materinity leave visit forest school paddington rec
story: But the Duchess of Cambridge clearly had her own children on her mind as she greeted students at the forest school in Paddington, cooing over a seven-month-old almost the same age as my little boy.The mother has been on maternity leave for five months, with her visit to Paddington Recreation Ground her first official solo event since giving birth to Prince Louis in April.And today the -year-old was inundated with young fans, left beaming as a little girl rushed forward to hug her around her waist.Kate, clearly surprised, laughed as the girl gripped her arms around her waist, and a second rushed in to make it a royal group hug.The duchess, wearing a khaki green Fjällräven jacket, a silk Joseph and Penelope Chilvers shirt, and riding boots, is today visiting Sayers Croft Forest School and Wildle Garden to see how it is helping childrens emotional and physical well-being.It was a charming start to Kates first official solo event since welcoming third child Louis into the world.The duchess made sure to speak to as many students and families as possible as she was taken around the facility - drawn in by some of the younger kids at her welcome.Meeting a seven-month-old boy called Romi at the Paddington Recreation Ground, Kate gushed: He’s very chatty, he’s almost the same age as my little boy.Prince Williams we seemed happy to spend time with the young St Stephens school students, listening to story time with Monkey Queen, read to them by Sayers Croft forest school leader Jennie Miles.The royal, who was gted posies by four-year-old Janine, also helped to hand out cups of juice and papers to make crowns.And she was left in stitches as one student promised there would be no boring bits on the tour.The duchess replied: This is so cool, I cant wait to see it.The seasoned royals visit even closed her car door herself - with a little help - after fans went crazy that her sister-in-law Meghan Markle was last week seen doing the same.The forest school, which had more than , visits by schoolchildren from across Westminster and neighbouring boroughs last year, gives inner city children the chance to engage with the natural world.Although the duchess has appeared at events such as the RAF centenary, Trooping the Colour and Wimbledon, and celebrated the Duke and Duchess of Sussexs wedding, this is her first official solo engagement since Louis arrival.The mum has previously spoken about her love for the outdoors, making todays visit the perfect fit for her .Visiting a primary school in South West London last November to see its gardening projects, she told pupils she had fond memories of being outdoors as a child.She also said she was passing that passion on to her own children.The duchess, who supports a number of mental health charities and initiatives, is passionate about offering children early social and emotional support.Its been a big year for Kate Middleton and the royal family, having welcomed several new members into the Firm this year.Meghan Markle married Prince Harry in a lavish ceremony in Windsor in May.Kate will also become an aunt when her sister Pippa Middleton gives birth to her first child.Pippa, who married financier James Matthews, , is expected to welcome a child this month.Kate was the first person after Pippa’s husband, James Matthews, to hear the good news.

title: car driving full tree branches stockport
story: His windscreen was obstructed and he couldnt reach the gear stick as he drove down Heaton Moor Road, Stockport.Police called the move absolute madness.PC Andy Monaghan said hed never seen anything like it and he had risked seriously injuring someone.The man in his s, who has not been named, had been doing gardening work for an elderly couple on September  and was taking the leafy branches to the tip when he was stopped by police.He decided to fill the blue Toyota Corolla to the brim with branches so he would only have to make one trip.But he was asked to empty his car in order to drive safely and then had to make multiple journeys to the tip to throw the branches away.He must now attend court accused of driving offences.PC Monaghan said: He thought hed be fine, but the weather was heavy and he had limited control.I wasnt shocked because Ive previously worked in traffic [but] it was absolute madness.

title: hounsdown school hampshire girls skirts distracting curvy figures
story: Ellie Porter and Jasmin Stacey, both , claim they were threatened with detention at Hounsdown School in Totton, Hampshire and told their MS skirts should be shin .Ellie Porter-Smith and her friend Jasmin Stacey, from Hampshire, were reportedly told their skirts were inappropriate and distractingEllies mum Gemma Porter claims one staff member suggested the skirts were inappropriate for curvy girls.She said she was horried the girls were being punished for their body shape because its out of their control.She said: [They] said our girls cant wear the skirts as theyre too close-fitting on them.[They] said its okay for girls with slender figures to wear the standard school skirt but its NOT okay for girls with curvy figures to wear it.Ms Porter claims the unorm issue came to light last month when Ellie ed to school after the summer break.She said she phoned the school to ask why the the skirt was deemed inappropriate - but claims she wasnt given a proper answer.She said: I asked who the skirt was distracting exactly, but the teacher wouldn’t say.I was just told that I had to get a new skirt by the morning or Ellie would be held in internal exclusion .Ms Porter said she decided to keep Ellie home the next day because she couldnt buy a skirt that evening. Jasmins mum, Emma, did the same.The two mums then agreed to take the girls shopping the next day at school outfitters School Kit, to ensure the right skirts were bought.Ms Porter said: It was really embarrassing for the girls. Standing there in the changing rooms in their pants, trying on skirts.They felt totally humiliated.”Ellie’s aunt Carly Hughes, from Gosport, took to Facebook to slam the school over the unorm row.She said her niece was “being punished for something out of her control, basically for being curvy and for skirts not fitting her body shape.The post - which has been shared more than , times - provoked fury among other parents, with several mums branding the school unreasonable. A Hounsdown School spokesman said: The school is unable to refer to or comment specically about an inidual student or complaint.However, in the event that a student comes to school in unorm that does not meet the school’s unorm policy, as set and agreed by the governing body, then in the first instance the school will contact the family to request alternative unorm.We have, where needed, supported students and families to source appropriate unorm items for students even going to shops to get unorm to assist parents and students in meeting the school’s unorm policy.Sun Online has approached Hounsdown School for further comment.

title: manchester university student union bans clapping jazz hands
story: The University of Manchester Students Union passed the resolution to ban clapping at their events at a meeting on September , according to student newspaper the Mancunion.The students will now use the British Sign Language clapping - or jazz hands - instead of traditional clapping, whooping, and cheering so that clapping can be more inclusive, according to the paper.It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues.BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression, the paper said.Sara Khan, the Liberation and Access Officer, authored the motion to encourage student groups and societies to do the same, and to include BSL clapping as a part of inclusion training.Each motion needs a  per cent majority to be passed and, according to the paper, Ms Khans motion faced little opposition.The Mancunion noted the National Union of Students has been using BSL clapping since .In April , delegates from the University of Durham proposed a motion which said that all clapping and whooping must be banned from future NUS events.The access needs of disabled students are disregarded overlooked in terms of conference member behaviour and NUS structures, it said, and called for “reduced cheering or unnecessary loud noises on conference floor, including whooping and clapping.In a statement to the , a spokesman for the NUS said they dont actively stop our members from clapping, they choose to be respectful.”

title: amazon raises minimum wage for uk and us staff after working conditions criticised
story: Amazon has come in for sustained criticism from unions and politicians because of the working conditions in its warehouses, as well as its failure to pay workers a living wage.Senator Bernie Sanders has accused the behemoth of underpaying its workers and forcing them to seek public assistance.In July, he tweeted: "While Jeff Bezos wealth increases by ma day, Amazon workers are afraid to take bathroom breaks at work and are grossly underpaid."Mr Bezos, Amazons founder and chief executive, has topped the rankings as the worlds richest man, with wealth in excess of bn .

title: brexit is turning traditional tory certainties on their head
story: But for the many critics of the Chequers plan within the party, the concerns of business on this front have been overstated, or at least over-prioritised by the Government.The recording that emerged of Boris Johnson saying "f*** business" was the most eye-catching expression of that perspective, but plenty of Tory MPs believe that some additional trade friction at borders is not only manageable, but a price worth paying for a Brexit that does not tie the UK to EU rules indefinitely.The fact that this disagreement boils down to a question of political priorities is one reason it has become so intractable within the party.

title: loss makers riding wall streets bull run
story: What is most breathtaking about this years IPOs in the US is the proportion of companies coming to market that have been loss-making.According to data compiled by Jay Ritter, professor of finance at the University of Floridas Warrington College of Business and one of the worlds foremost experts on IPOs, some % of companies to have floated in the US this year do not make a profit.His findings, first reported in the Wall Street Journal, cover the period since .Recent examples highlighted by the Journal include SVMK, the owner of online survey provider SurveyMonkey, whose shares jumped by % on its stock market debut last week despite it never having made a profit.Tech stocks have been at the forefront of this, including the cloud company Dropbox, whose prospectus even warned that it may never become profitable.Other well-known, but as yet unprofitable, tech companies to have floated this year include DocuSign, the electronic signature technology company, whose shares floated at  each in April but which closed on Monday evening at ..Carbon Black, a cyber security firm yet to make a profit, saw its shares float at  in May and then rise to  before falling back. Music streaming service Spoty is probably the most high-profile tech company to have floated this year without ever having made a profit.But this phenomenon of flotations involving non-profitable companies does not only reflect the ongoing popularity of tech stocks.It also reflects surging interest in biotech stocks and also the boom in cannabis-related companies.

story: NewsHome Secretary Sajid Javid says we will fight hope in very unfortunate conference speech slip of the tongueMr Javid was attempting to paint a vision of a tolerant Britain but there was a glaring errorShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video sajid-javid-says-we-fight-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHome Secretary Sajid Javid had an embarrassing slip up as he delivered his conference speech. Mr Javid was attempting to paint a vision of a tolerant Britain but there was a glaring error. He said: We will fight fear with optimismprejudice with tolerance. We will fight, er, hope... er.. hate! Fight against hate with hope.He told Tory members that leaving the EU gave the UK the chance to come together praising what he called he path of Modern Britain.Tolerant Britain.Global Britain. In his conference speech Sajid Javid also warned against backtracking on the Brexit referendum result.He said: To meet our best potential, we need to bring the country together - the worst way to do that, would be to backtrack on the referendum result. If Brexit feels like a iding line in our country now, just imagine what it would feel likewe didnt follow through with the result of the referendum. He added: So, lets get on with it. No second-guessing, no best-of-three, one vote, one mandate, one nation moving forwards together. Mr Javid said the existing Le in the UK test for new citizens was not enough.  He said: Citizenship should mean more than being able to win a pub quiz. We need to make it a British values test - and thats exactly what I will bring in. Mr Javid also addressed the scandal of child grooming gangs, describing it as one of the most shocking state failures he could remember.  He said: I will not let cultural or political sensitivities get in the way of understanding the problem and doing something about it. It is a statement of fact - a fact which both saddens and angers me - that most of the men in recent high-profile gang convictions have had Pakistani heritage. This behaviour is a disgrace to that heritage. So, Ive instructed my officials to look into this unflinchingly, and where the evidence suggests that there are certain cultural factors driving this, I will not hesitate to act.  Mr Javid also outlined further proposals to deal with forced marriage, including refusing spousal entry to the UK where there is evidence of it occurring. title: theresa booed over brexit tory
story: NewsTheresa May booed over Brexit by her OWN Tory members as furious mutiny mounts to her plan for leaving EUThe humiliating claims came as a kickback went into full swing at the Tory conference - with a former Brexit minister saying Mrs Mays plan are causing "considerable alarm"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLocal chairman reportedly heckled their leader as she defended her Chequers proposal "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has been booed by her own Tory members at the party conference as a huge backlash mounts to her plan for Brexit. Local chairman reportedly heckled their leader as she defended her Chequers proposal at a behind-closed-doors meeting of the National Conservative Convention. Attendee John Stafford told the Dailyit was a wave of grumbling adding: The party leader normally gets a standing ovation... but Mrs May just walked off and that was it. This is my th party conference and Ive never seen that. Another person in the room said: There was a boo when she mentioned Chequers. It was a bit embarrassing. The humiliating claims came as a kickback went into full swing in Birmingham - with a former Brexit minister saying Mrs Mays plan are causing Brexiteer members considerable alarm. Steve Baker said the blueprint - which will see the UK share a common rulebook with Brussels on some goods exports - takes off the table all of the benefits of an independent trade and regulatory policy.  He also claimed US officials despair of Chequers as it would leave Britain as a satellite of the EU. The row erupted as Boris Johnson prepares to take the axe to Mrs Mays Chequers plan in a speech to the conference this lunchtime.  And Brexiteers are set to be enraged even further - as reports emerged Mrs May will compromise even further with the EU. The Times reported the Prime Minister is preparing a grand bargain offer to Brussels that would involve the UK staying tied to EU customs rules on goods after a transition period ends in December . If true this would bar Britain from striking global trade deals for many years.  Its reported that this temporary arrangement would have no time limit - and end only when a technological solution to the Irish border issue was found. Mrs May today admitted her husband Philip poured her a stf drink after EU chiefs told her last month that her Chequers plan will not work. She is still trapped in deadlock with the EU, with each side urging the other to budge just days before a crucial Brussels summit.  The gathering on October  to  has been billed as the moment of truth when it will become clear whether it is possible for the two sides to do a deal. But talks have become trapped over the issue of the Irish border. Mrs May says the EUs plan would drive a wedge between rules for Northern Ireland and those for the rest of the UK - essentially, a border down the Irish Sea. Chancellor Philip Hammond upped the ante last night in a drastic warning thattheres no deal, full border checks WILLbetween Northern Ireland and the Republic.  He told a fringe event at the Tory conference: The challenges around the Irish border are around the legal requirements we will havewe are not in a trade block within the European Union to operate the [World Trade Organisation] compliant border, which does require checks at the border. That’s what the WTO rules require.” European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker hit back this morning - saying the EU would not compromise on key principles, and there must be agreement on the Irish borderMrs May wants a Brexit deal. We want to have a deal, he said.  Those who think a no-deal would be a better solution are not aware of the dficulties such a scenario would imply. When it comes to the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, we are sticking to the point of view we have expressed so many times - Ireland first. Mr Juncker also suggested British planes may not be able to land in the EUBrexit goes wrong. And he warned a four-day quarantine may be imposed on pet dogs and cats passing from the UK to continental Europe and again on theirjourney. Speaking at a public meeting in Freiburg, Germany, Mr Juncker asked: Whats going to happen to air traffic in Europeeverything goes wrong  British planes will not be able to land on the European continent. People didnt know that. Someone should have told them beforehand. The UKs current Brexit plan is based on a deal Theresa May drew up at Chequers, her country retreat, in July . At the time it was seen as a major sht to soft Brexit - prompting hard-Leaver Cabinet ministers David Davis and Boris Johnson to resign. The Facilitated Customs Arrangement is a bid to solve the biggest problem of Brexit - how to stop a hard border between Northern Ireland and either the EU, or the rest of the UK. It would keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. Under this plan, the UK would share a common rulebook with Brussels for goods, including agricultural and food products. Britain would also collect some, but not all, customs tarfs on the EUs behalf. Parliament would technically keep the right to block future rules. But Tory Brexiteers said this olive branch would useless in practice. They forced Theresa May to amend the plan to say the EU should collects tarfs on the UKs behalf. Mrs May insisted this didnt scupper her plan. But EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier disagreed, and has continued to suggest there will be a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Remainers and Labour have also opposed the Chequers plan, saying it leaves Britain half-in-half-out of the EU in the worst of all worlds.With a November deadline to agree a deal with the EU looming, and the plan facing a vote in Parliament after that, the UK is now ramping up plans to leave in March  with no deal.

title: what tory brexit going look
story: NewsopinionThis is what the Tory Brexit is going to look likeTheres bad news for borders, badgers and BorisShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are  days until Brexit, theyve got a full tank of prats, half a pack of loons, theyre doomed and theyre wearing blue rosettes. Welcome to the Conservative Party conference of , where the Tories are trying to pretend they can organise a knees-up that doesnt somehow end in whacking themselves in the testicles.Its day one, and theyve already failed. Their Great Blond Hope has not only been victim of a Big Daddy splash by Lord Digby Jones, hes been impersonated by Phil Voldemort Hammond and had his ideas characterised as not much good by David Mine Are No Better Davis.We are now uncomfortably close to the arbitrary date for leaving the European Union, chosen by a Prime Minister who herself was chosen because she wasnt someone , and as is the way with things on horizons it looks worryingly like an out-of-control hydrogen explosion.We all know whats happened - the referendum supposed to uny the Tories has caused them to turn on each other like cannibals who gave up chlorinated chicken for Lent, the question supposed to be settled for a generation remains unanswered, and Theresa May is still PM primarily because she isnt someone .So what is Brexit going to look like, under the Tories  . Project Oh Dear Jeremy Hunt is a man who has more in common with an Anglepoise lamp than the rest of the human race. He can be pointed, turned on, and turned off again, but usually fails to illuminate anyone. He is now second-favourite to be Prime Minister next year, which should be adequate proof of just how boked the Tories are.Boris is trolling, Sajid and Gavin are manoeuvring, Chris Grayling is in a siding outside Melton Mowbray and Hunt - a man who, the Leveson Inquiry heard, tried to hide behind trees to avoid journalists while still being visible to them - is now, let me say it again, one of the favourites. Its a bit like saying the green Opal Fruit is your favourite. Or that the USSR, which invaded countries that tried to leave it and killed millions, is just like the EU, which negotiates, even with people who dont know what theyre doing. . Project You Cant Be Serious  Having toured the country in a bus promising to give our EU subscription to the NHS, the Tories have since said: a well still have to pay a subscription b it will be higher, without a rebatec by the way, well be cutting pound.bn off the NHSToday the spiritual leader of the Brextremists has suggested we spend our foreign aid budget on saving elephants, because they remind him of Beethovens Fth Symphony. Hang the education projects, stuff the small-scale charities who exist entirely because of foreign aid, and lets get all worked up about the  pence in every pound national profit that we spend on foreigners. Boo hiss to foreigners! Elephants are British! Wait, what  . Project Is This Really The Best You Could Do  Brexit, the Tories are assuring us and their donors, will mean a bonfire of unnecessary rules and regulations about meaningless, bureaucratic tripe like child car seats, not getting killed at work and hiding your money from the taxman.It gives us a chance to set our own rules such as only banning dangerous cladding  months after it burned  people alive, and onlyits on new buildings, which means all the people living in older properties can go sizzle.It also wont matteryou sleep surrounded by highly-flammable material on the sixth floor, oryou dont have a sprinkler system, or the fire exits are blocked or non-existent. After Brexit, you wont want to live anyway. . Project Genuine Fear  The government of the UK is trying to exit a union it doesnt want while protecting one that it does. To do so they are relying on a referendum they say must be respected, while ignoring a referendum they say must be over-ridden.All the people concerned were told beforehand that Brexit would spell the end of the Good Friday Agreement, a hard-won peace in Northern Ireland, and possibly the end of the Union altogether. That they have now,  months from doom, had this explained to them again by a comedian shows just what a bad joke the Tories are.Patrick Kieltys dad was murdered by the Ulster Freedom Fighters for exposing their organised crime. The Tories border solution involves asking those self-same people to pretend theres a border where there isnt one, and file paperwork well in advance before smuggling guns, drugs and people across  miles of hedge that we cant police. Laugh  Youll die. . Project It All Onto Someone Else Presiding over economic chaos  Watching John Lewis go down the pan, the world turn against you, and Jacob Rees-Mogg destroying all his own suggestions by moving his investment funds to the EU and trying to get a trade deal with the Peoples Republic of Jam Jar Or Something Like That  Well, why not shoot some more badgers. Not in the head, thats too quick. Kneecap them and watch them suffer. Burn some cattle, bankrupt some farmers, blame it all on the EUs crazy rules about bovine TB which isnt harmless so long as you pasteurise your milk, mostly doesnt kill cows and could easily be stopped with a vaccineonly we could be bothered.When someone says but Brexit means we can abandon these rules! Save the badgers! point out we still have to abide by EU ruleswe want to sell beef, milk or cheese to the EU. And dont, for heavens sake, let anyone say that the only way to change those rules is to, er, remain in the EU.With a Tory Brexit, hard or soft, youre looking at Jeremy Hunt being in charge while making swingeing NHS cuts, making it quite the worst reboot of a franchise since Indiana Jones And The Hospital Of Doom.Youll see people burning in another tower block before long, a fresh wave of terrorism when we havent dealt with the current one, and Tories blaming badgers, migrants, and anything  that moved because, after Brexit, theyll no longer be able to blame the EU. The Tories have spent the past  years blaming Europe for all the things they cocked up themselves. Without the EU, people are going to blame the Tories. Which is why their days are numbered.

title: how lost nearly 3m one
story: News"How I lost nearly £m in one day": Former professional rugby player reveals how he built and lost a fortuneTommy Nelmes had  properties at the height of his empire but lost it all in the credit crunchShareCommentsByNick Lavigueur:,  OCT NewsTommy Nelmes at home in Aspley where he described how the bank asked for nearly £ million to be paid back in one working day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former rugby league professional has opened up about how he lost a property empire in just one day. Tommy Nelmes, a hooker for the Huddersfield Giants in the s, became a property magnate only to lose it all in the blink of an eye when he was given just one day to pay pound.m. The -year-old, who grew up at in Sheepridge, Huddersfield, signed on with his hometown team in .But his career was sadly cut short just a year later aged just  when he severely damaged his elbow, Examiner Live reports.Using his pound, compensation pay-out, he began a new career as a landlord, buying a few cheap homes in Lockwood to rent out. Over the next  years, he built up his portfolio to more than  homes at one point and was making a decent living of about pound, per year, at one point in the early s. With his properties at one point bringing in pound, a year, Tommy enjoyed holidays in the Caribbean and had a large property of his own in Almondbury.  But things started to go sour in  when he tried to re-mortgage his portfolio, mostly rented to council tenants, at the peak of the so-called Credit Crunch. In a bid to consolidate all his lending and free up some equity from his homes, he approached Northern Rock – which unknown to him was on the verge of financial collapse. Tommy applied to borrow pound.m on the basis that his portfolio of  homes was worth in excess of poundm. Northern Rock loaned him the cash just a few months before it was bailed out by taxpayers and eventually taken over by Virgin Money. Fast forward four years and Northern Rock said it wanted to re-value the portfolio. Due to Tommy’s health problems and issues with valuation companies, it was another two years before a valuation was done and the former athlete was dealt a huge blow. It was revealed that his properties had been over-valued by an incredible pound.m. The huge reduction in value led the mortgage firm to believe the loan-to-value rate was double what it could tolerate and a huge risk to its investment. On July , , Northern Rock sent a formal demand for repayment of the whole debt, some pound.m. Tommy claimed he was only given one working day to settle the bill and no payment was ever made. The firm quickly moved in, repossessing all the homes, including his own house, and evicting his tenants.  They were all sold on in a bid to recoup the mortgage debt. Five years on, after two failed bids in court to claw back some of his legacy, Tommy says he still feels unfairly dealt with. A group of judges awarded him a pound, procurement fee back – but which he is yet to receive. In court, a judge disagreed with Tommys claim that he only had a day to pay but did concede that Northern Rock had rushed the enforcement process by appointing receivers before the deadline it had set. Tommy, whose son Luke Nelmes plays rugby league for Oldham in the third tier of the professional game, said he hadn’t given up hope of getting something back one day. “The unfairness is overwhelming,” he said. “The first ten properties cost me pound, - by  those same ten were worth pound.m. “I had houses in Spain, America, Portugal and I used to love going to Barbados. You work hard, you play hard.

title: lottery winner broke girlfriends jaw
story: NewsLottery winner broke girlfriends jaw in childrens hospital when she tried to dump him for blowing cash on drugsDavid Bonnick, , chased his partner Ellen Sweeney into Bristol Childrens Hospital and floored her with a vicious punchShareCommentsByGeoff Bennett:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEllen Sweeney was in a relationship with David Bonnickfor some three years, Bristol Crown Court heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Lottery winner who descended into drug and alcohol addiction after scooping pound, has been jailed for attacking his partner in a drunken rage. David Bonnick was just  when he landed the windfall on a scratchcard and quit his job. He became an alcoholic and started using cocaine after falling in with the wrong crowd, Bristol Crown Court heard. Hes now been jailed for  months for attacking his girlfriend Ellen Sweeney when she finished with him. She was so scared of him she thought it would be safer to end it in public when he attended an appointment at the Bristol Royal Infirmary.  But Bonnick, now , did not react well and followed her in a furious rage to the adjoining Bristol Childrens Hospital, where he floored her with a vicious punch. title: mums shock shes told shes
story: NewsMums shock as shes told shes let herself go after having kids - but then she realises something brilliantAn encounter with an old friend left mum-of-three Amy Weatherly wonderingshed let herself goShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAmys friend was shocked by how dferent she looked after having kids "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn high school, Amy Weatherly was the girl who only wore wedges and trendy tops. She never went anywhere without make-up, big hair and jewelery and was voted the girliest girl and most likely to wear heels in her year.The writer and mother-of-three didnt think too much about her had changed, until she recently ran into an old friend from school who made a few comments that hit a little too close to home. But instead of wallowing in her feelings and getting down, Amy hit back in an inspirational Facebook post. The -year-old from Texas wrote: I saw a friend I hadn’t seen in a while today. We chatted and hugged and she laughed and said I can’t believe I’m seeing you out in public with no makeup and tennis shoes. Who even are you anymore  I laughed because it’s true. In a past le, in a galaxy far far away, I was the girl never without jewelry, and lip gloss, and loads of foundation. I had myself together. I was voted “girliest girl” and “most likely to wear heels” for crying out loud. And now... Well, now is a completely dferent story.Amy then joked to her friend that having that third baby really forced [her] to let [herself] go.She continued: We chatted for another minute, about this and that and nothing important. We hugged, promised to grab lunch soon, knew we probably never would, and went our separate ways.  But I kept thinking about my words, they kept rolling through my head over and over that day and left me feeling like crap: let myself go. I knew I didnt look the same as I did before, but had I actually let myself go  Ten extra lbs and a messy bun would point to yes, but my heart screamed HECK TO THE NO YOU HAVE NOT, GIRLFRIEND. Im more confident now. Im more sure of myself. Im less likely to cry over a breakout, or miss out on a night with my girls because of dirty hair. Truth is, I kind of like myself now, definitely more than I did before. I wouldn’t go back to that girl with the good hair for all the skinny jeans and skinny lattes in the world.  Amy then asked why it is we continue to use the phrase let herself go and saidpeople just took a step back and thought about it all for a moment, theyd realise they hadnt let themselves go at all. There’s a good chance we’ll discover they have in fact found themselves and appreciated themselves and loved themselves and realized that who they are as a human has absolutely nothing to do with their fake eyelashes or their highlights or their giant leathery feathery earrings , and absolutely everything to do with their heart, and their mind, and their soul, she proclaimed. She ended her post by reminding other parents that they are so much more than just a pretty face. You haven’t let yourself go. Stop saying that. It’s rude. It’s derogatory, and it’s downright absurd. You haven’t let yourself go, you have simply let go of the need to look perfect all of the time, she said. Put on makeup when you can, get your hair did when you find the time, pamper yourself, take care of yourself, splurge on a new outfit and don’t you dare feel bad about it for one second — just know that none of those outside things define you. Not anymore. They aren’t you. They are things, and there is a huge dference between the two. You are more than just a pretty face.  You are a momma. You are a we. You are a sister. You are a lover. You are a fighter. You are a warrior. You are a daughter. You are a student. You are a teacher. You are a dreamer. You are a doer. You are a giver. You are a believer. You are you, and that can never be taken away from you. The emotional post has been liked over , times and shared more than  times. Many women said that they were grateful to have read it.

story: NewsAncient Buddhist shrine left looking like Lego after botched restoration paint jobOne critic said the shrine carved into a mountainside looked like a childrens drawing - with another questioning whether the work could be classed as vandalismShareCommentsByScott FengDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT NewsThe Buddhist cave after the restoration "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A millennium-old Buddhist shrine carved into a mountainside has been likened to Lego and a childs artwork after a botched restoration job.Each Buddhist statue at the cave shrine in south-western Chinas Sichuan province has been coloured in. Many have said the hallowed figures now look more than childrens toys, with several people online calling them Lego figures. Before and after images of the bizarre restoration show a corrugated iron roof having been placed over the holy area in order to shelter it from the rain. No official government organisation has claimed responsibility for the botched job, which social media user Niehuaxiong said looked like a nursery school drawing.  The shrine is believed to date back to the Tang dynasty , when devotees chiselled nine Buddha statues in the rock face. However, after the sacred shrine began to fade from existence due to long-term exposure to the elements, local experts are thought to have taken it upon themselves to restore it to its former glory. Members of the public believe the job was done by unofficial local artists without the blessing of officials whose task is to oversee such projects. Commenter coldmocho asked: Is this considered vandalism of cultural relics  It is unclear whether the Tang dynasty cave shrine had been listed as a cultural heritage site.  has previously reported on an ancient Spanish town that shot to international fame when an old church masterpiece was restored with hilarious results.

story: NewsIndonesia earthquake: Final words of air traffic controller who sacriced own le to save plane carrying hundredsAnthonius Gunawan Agung was the only worker left in the air traffic control tower after his colleagues fled in terror and stayed behind to make sure a plane carrying hundreds of passengers could take off safelyShareCommentsByYishu NgYimin WooElaine McCahill:,  OCT NewsAnthonius Gunawan Agung stayed behind in the crumbling traffic control tower to make sure a plane carrying hundreds could take off safely as the earthquake hit "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Indonesian pilot hailed an air traffic controller who died in Fridays earthquake as aangel for ensuring a passenger plane took off safely before he jumped in vain for safety. Anthonius Gunawan Agung, , was among at least , people who died in the devastating .-magnitude quake and tsunami that hit Sulawesi island.When disaster struck, Agung stayed behind in the crumbling four-storey control tower at Palu airport to make sure a plane carrying hundreds of passengers could take off.Agung, , refused to leave the tower despite the danger and he was the only worker left as he guided Batik Air flight  to safety.  Agungs last words, according to pilot Ricoseta Mafella, were: Batik , runway , clear for takeoff. He was saying it in a very calm manner, because the earthquake hadnt started yet, Mafella told Reuters. Then the earthquake struck. I felt that the aircraft was moving slightly to the right and to the left, Mafella said. Agung waited for the plane, bound from Palu to Makassar, to become airborne before leaving the control tower, authorities said. He stayed... until the last of my departure, until the tower was shaking very bad, Mafella added.  Once he made sure that the aircraft had departed safely, he jumped from his tower to the lower level. He suffered internal injuries and a broken leg, and was rushed to hospital by his colleagues. A helicopter was ordered to take him to a dferent hospital for specialist care, and he was transported back to Mutiara SIS Al-Jufrie Airport on Saturday morning to be picked up. However, he died before the helicopter arrived.  Air Nav Indonesia spokesman Yohannes Sirait said Mr Agungs decision to stay behind cost him his le, but he may have saved hundreds of others. The airline also said in a statement that it would posthumously raise Agungs rank by two levels as a sign of appreciation. The company tweeted out images showing Agungs body being carried to a helicopter during his funeral procession in Makassar.

story: NewsRussian town spooked by creepy VOODOO DOLLS covered in needles - and theyre making residents illResidents warn a curse has been put on their village following the appearance of the mystery mannequinsShareCommentsByWill StewartNeil Murphy:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video russian-town-littered-creepy-voodoo-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Russian city has been spooked by the sudden appearance of sinister “voodoo dolls” spiked with needles.Pensioners complained of blood pressure problems after seeing the haunting mannequins at dozens of locations. One local complained: ”Creepy dolls are nailed to the pillars, fences and bus stops in Zavetny on the outskirts of Armavir in Krasnodar region. “The little girl mannequins are pierced with needles and tied with black threads.” Residents called for an explanation of the dozens of weird dolls which appeared overnight. There were complaints to police. “Two were sitting at a bus stop,” said another householder.  “A doll in a in a pink ball gown was found in the park.” A local warned: “A curse has been put on our village.” Several were eyeless or one-armed. They were dressed in girls clothes or school unorms. Head of the local council Dmitry Barkov said: “We have urgently brought together police officers to instruct them to calm people.” Police are studying CCTV cameras to identy those who distributed the dolls around the area even though planting voodoo dolls is not a crime, say reports. Meanwhile a local security officer has admitted dumping the mannequins - “the same size as a child” - at a local tip. Tatiana Kokoreva claimed they belonged to a local culture museum and were previously used in a puppet theatre which closed long ago.

title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of #Csaba out# rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United#s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprisehe is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on  minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird#s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals # often carbon copies of each other.The second came on  minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On  minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on  minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay#s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on  minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United#s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba Full details in live blog.

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s - win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a - thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s - defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee united sack manager csaba laszlo
story: Dundee United have parted company with manager Csaba Laszlo following yesterday#s - home thumping by Ross CountyThe club and Csaba have mutually agreed to end his contract effective today, with No  Laurie Ellis taking over on an interim basis.Dundee United chairman Mike Martin said: #I would like to thank Csaba for the considerable commitment he showed during his time at Dundee United and for his contribution to improving the underpinning football structure at the club.#We wish him all the best for the future. I can also confirm that Laurie Ellis has taken interim management responsibility for the team.#Ellis will likely be in the dugout for Saturday#s trip to face Ayr United in the Ladbrokes Championship as the Terrors look to appoint a replacement for Csaba.The Hungarian took up the post himself on November  last year and leaves the Tangerines sitting fourth in the table and five points behind leaders Ayr.

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make ato the city.The -times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November .Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance toto the national team at  years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park  years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although -years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September , a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in .The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No  shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet  Greet briefs – are on sale from am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.Help For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.
